justification: The article states that "the dictator game serves as a measure of the trade-off between self-interest (keeping all the money for the self) and other-interest (giving away some or all of the money to the other)."

When introducing this variant, the authors note prior work showing that giving decreases and the half-endowment peak diminishes, treating these behavioral changes as indicators of prosocial (altruistic) motives measured with the take-option version of the dictator game.

The paper explains that the "extreme dictator games" were "specifically designed to investigate the influence of language on altruistic behavior," indicating that this game variant operationalizes altruism.
